instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

threads.title: 820-3476 with short on ppbus_g3h
threads.message:
I've got a 820-3476 which is only showing 1v on PPBUS_G3H and about 300 ohms to ground.

There was corrosion around R1410 and R1617 which I've cleaned up and repaired during my first pass over the board, but apart from that it's clean with no other visible issues.

Pulled F7140 and showing 12.7v on pin 1 with a 155ohm, and 500ohm on pin 2.

Any suggestions on the best way forward?

threads.title: 820-3476 with short on ppbus_g3h
threads.message:
Check if any big coil has the same value to ground.
L7520/60 for example...

threads.title: 820-3476 with short on ppbus_g3h
threads.message:
L7520 has 420 to ground on both legs
L7560 is 150 on both legs...

threads.title: 820-3476 with short on ppbus_g3h
threads.message:
L7430 is 125 on both legs
L3095 is 500 on both legs
L7320 & L7310 are 50 on both legs

threads.title: 820-3476 with short on ppbus_g3h
threads.message:
Post EXACT ohm value to ground on both pins of R7202; red probe to ground.
Also check PPBUS_G3H value to ground removing U7501.
Be AWARE, do NOT power up the board without U7501!!!
Also check removing F7700 and Q3080.

BTW, post first diode mode to ground on PPBUS_G3H with black probe to ground.
Maybe you do NOT have any issue there...

threads.title: 820-3476 with short on ppbus_g3h
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 52231"]Post EXACT ohm value to ground on both pins of R7202; red probe to ground..[/QUOTE]

Pin 1 - 484ohm
Pin 2 - 475ohm

[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 52231"]Also check PPBUS_G3H value to ground removing U7501.
Be AWARE, do NOT power up the board without U7501!!![/QUOTE]

I'll come back to you on this.

[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 52231"]Also check removing F7700 and Q3080.[/QUOTE]

I'll come back to you on this.

[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 52231"]BTW, post first diode mode to ground on PPBUS_G3H with black probe to ground.
Maybe you do NOT have any issue there..[/QUOTE]

With black to ground this is open (checked on pin 2 of F7140)...

threads.title: 820-3476 with short on ppbus_g3h
threads.message:
"Pin 2 - 475ohm
With black to ground this is open (checked on pin 2 of F7140)"
Then looks like good values.
If PPBUS_G3H disappears when solder F7040, you should have problem with some secondary supply.
Probably 3/5V, change U7501 for test.

threads.title: 820-3476 with short on ppbus_g3h
threads.message:
Back down to 1.6v on PPBUS_G3H.

I'll swap U7501 and report back.

threads.title: 820-3476 with short on ppbus_g3h
threads.message: Swapped U7501 and it looks like we're still the same.

threads.title: 820-3476 with short on ppbus_g3h
threads.message: Post exact resistance between pins 17/18 and 27/28 of U7100.

threads.title: 820-3476 with short on ppbus_g3h
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 52240"]Post exact resistance between pins 17/18 and 27/28 of U7100.[/QUOTE]

17 & 18: 4 ohms
27 & 28: 718 ohms

threads.title: 820-3476 with short on ppbus_g3h
threads.message:
"27 & 28: 718 ohms"
Check schematic and fix that...

threads.title: 820-3476 with short on ppbus_g3h
threads.message: Replaced C7120 and U7100, but that resistance remains. Damage in the board, or have I missed something?

threads.title: 820-3476 with short on ppbus_g3h
threads.message:
Don't you think to check R7021/22???
And traces, of course...

threads.title: 820-3476 with short on ppbus_g3h
threads.message: Yes, all tested OK, but it looks like my replacement U7100 might have been dead, I've swapped it again and we have fan spin. Need to test fully, but looks like it's OK. Thanks for your help!

threads.title: 820-3476 with short on ppbus_g3h
threads.message: Do you have correct resistance between pins 27/28 now???

threads.title: 820-3476 with short on ppbus_g3h
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 52331"]Do you have correct resistance between pins 27/28 now???[/QUOTE]

Yep, 20ohms, which seems consistent with reference boards.

threads.title: 820-3476 with short on ppbus_g3h
threads.message: One post appeared later, seems like your problem is already solved...
